comments.commentBody:
I would not call what Trump is doing with the gun zealots "courting"; try "supplicate", or "pander", or "embrace".

There are better, more colourful words the Times could have used, (and it's Trump we're talking about so it should only be 'the best' words, unbelievable words...).
A detailed, rational debate will be impossible as long as the entire Republican Party is bought and paid for by the NRA .

“We’re going to do a lot better because there’s going to be a shootout.”
Tell that to the police in Dallas.

The NRA has been attacking HRC for years. Just look at any video of a gun review. I am a strong advocate of the 2nd, a hunter and socially liberal. The NRA does not represent me. They only represent manufacturers and most are made overseas.

I'm a donor to the Clinton campaign and an AR 15 owner.  I bought it for a hunting application where I needed multiple shots, but not much power (it's an urban myth that it uses a powerful cartridge).  No, most owners are not criminals or crazy, as is oft stated in this paper.  I bought the gun way too easily and would have been happy to jump through major hoops, like those currently in place for machine gun purchases, because I'm serious gun enthusiast.  As a Democrat I fear she will lose too many states over her rhetoric about reviving the assault weapons ban.   Semi autos like the AR and the AK have been the most popular rifles sold in the US for many, many years; I am confident that millions of owners have a "come and take it" attitude and will be criminalized rather than turn them in--or will sell them privately with no records.  That will create a gigantic black market in these guns and especially parts--they are modular and very popular to customize and so there are BILLIONS of parts in circulation for tens of millions of ARs and AKs.  She and Diane Feinstein had better get some young people in the room to face this problem realistically, because the 1990 style CA/NY thinking could have disastrous results for our country in ways simply not being discussed in the urban papers.
the nra, 5% of our population, control the masses. but i isn't the membership pawns - it's almost exclusively the manufactures with the firepower...

So Democrats think that that the wedge issue is gun control? Among the working class that they abandoned, or among disaffected Republicans?

Not likely.

This is just Kite-Flying by both sides, Trump was just too stupid to let Hillary be first to get her kite up in the air.
There used to be a time when most Democrats wouldn't dare run afoul of the NRA. We can at least be thankful for clearly drawn battle lines now.

Let's put "well regulated" back into the Second Amendment.
I know it's there in words, but these days not in spirit.
Using your own numbers, 240,00 gun deaths since 2007 and a total of 573 (net of suicides)  by concealed carry holders tells me there is a much, much, much bigger problem than CCH.

If, in fact, a good guy with a gun can stop a bad guy with a gun, the NRA would be shouting it from the rooftops. The lone shooter with an assault rifle expects things like nobody would anticipate an ambush, getting as many people killed in a few seconds and that the carnage will be over before that good guy can reach their gun.
And stand your ground is purely based on an implication of threat. If that were true of just a way of killing someone who aggravates someone, then all women and children would be armed to the teeth. These two groups are under constant threat but they aren't packing!
This is domestic terrorism and the gun lobby and NRA and manufacturers are no different from the Saudis who have backed and supported extremists unabashedly for year.

When you have an election, it's an opportunity to discuss the most serious problems facing our nation. On the verge of the Civil War, you don't discuss tariffs.  On the verge of the Depression, you don't discuss the salaries of Congressmen. It would be nice if the candidates discussed the logjam in Congress and climate change.

I really like the sound of the phrase in this article about Hillary's "gun *safety* agenda." Sounds better and is more accurate and to the point than "gun control." She should adopt that language for her campaign.

If the New York Times is going to continue to carry the mantle of anti-gun zealots, I want them to pledge to their readers that they will never again support or promote any actions by the U.S. Military.

You can't have your cake and eat it too.

comments.userLocation: Oklahoma City, OK and Baton Rouge, LA
comments.commentBody: The letters USA are perfect: The United States of Armaments.

I agree with the sentiment here - especially in the last paragraph. In one sense, I'm glad to see Trump embrace the NRA - he may take it with him when he sinks out of out view and out of our consciousness following the election. He and the NRA are a match made in heaven although I suspect that is not where they are headed. Bon voyage...

EB's essay in an exercise in sophistry, conflating constitutionalism with zealotry, second amendment adovocacy with fanaticism. As I have mentioned, I neither own a gun,and despise hunting innocent animals for "sport," an act of cowardice.Nonetheless, in today's polarized political climate,where tensions between communities, as well as the threats from the Caliphate r ever present, a gun is necessary for self defense.Would the mass shooter Charles Whitman been able to pick off students from his perch at the U.of Texas in 1966 if there had been a sharpshooter on the ground able to return fire? Would the victims in San Bernardino be alive if someone among them  had been holstered?Problem of whether to allow assault weapons to be sold or not is one without a solution, and we must never forget the needless loss of life at Ruby Ridge, caused by a government sniper.Those who speak out against gun violence here, such as Ms. Clinton, surrounded by her own praetorian guard of Secret Service agents,"armes jusqu'aux dents,"ignore our government's complicity in the international arms trade. We control 40 percent  of the market, and much of the weaponry is sold to brutal dictatorships to be used against domestic political opponents.Why is this not a fit subject of discussion?Likewise Obama's use of bombing strikes and drone attacks against the enemy  in Syria and Iraq targeting Al Queda and ISIS, but taking the lives of innocents as well.
Not all gun owners are nuts but, since all people have the potential of going nuts, that makes the gun owners much more dangerous.

When Trump calls for volunteers to be vigilant at the polls, I assume he is calling on the "Gun Zealots" to be armed at the polls to defend against alleged "cheating." Or is it yet another way to disenfranchise non-gun-owner and other "undesireables" from voting?

Time for Obama to make an executive order that fed agents leave their guns at work, especially if they have kids. And why not local cops too? Expand the fed authority!
Those groups have strong unions to protect their rights because their lives( and big pensions matter ).

The National Rifle Association has made a grave mistake, if it has indeed officially endorsed Trump. Although many have called him "dangerous", like Hamilton called Burr, I doubt whether Trump would be willing to meet one of his detractors at 10 to 25 paces on a cliff above the Hudson.
There are many reasons for deaths, caused by firearms in the US, and no one has yet come up with a solution of how to control them. Possible ways are (1) strict controls at the point of sales and (2) education, starting at an early age, of the nature, respect to, and use of firearms.

In the interest of full disclosure, I am for the citizen's right as specified in Amendment II to the US Constitution and as one of "the natural rights of self-defense, resistance to oppression, and the civic duty to act in concert in defense of the state" (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Second_Amendment_to_the_United_States_Cons....

The NRA represents only 4% of gun owners (350,000,000 + genes in the US, 110,000,000 gun owners, 4,000,000 NRA members). The solution to the gun problem is to take illegal guns away from young black men and children who are shooting and killing other black men and children. If we can't talk about this because it's politically incorrect or because the politically incorrect think it's racist, then we are doomed to have much more of the same.
By the way, the community did a nice job in Milwaukee last night, don't you think?

Your attack on Donald Trump's support of the National Rifle Association is disingenous. N.R.A members are not gun zealots just because they support our 2nd Amendment right to own a gun. You argument conceals the real issue with its ad hominem smear of millions of gun owners.
Yours is a top-down view of government power to infringe on our Bill of Rights. Your argument naturally supports Mrs. Bill Clinton's view of government. And for her, control of the White House means patronage power dispensing "favors" or denying the "favor" ---- the word Clinton aide Huma Abedin uses in a Clinton email response to a donor and campaign supporter looking for the Clinton Foundation to hire someone. But a Constitutional right is not in government's power to decide whether the people can exercise it.
While deriding the "good guy" with a gun for self-protection ---- though most people understand that phrase to mean a law-abiding, well-trained gun owner ---- neither Hillary Clinton nor the Times editorial board tells us whom they would allow to own a gun, and for which reasons. Readers, please note the editorial omission.
When our 2nd Amendment states that "government shall not infringe on the right of the people to bear arms" it means that individual citizens have the right to own a gun. It says "people," not "gun zealots." And our 1st Amendment uses the same language as the 2nd in stating that it "prohibits government laws "infringing with the right to peaceably assemble..."

It's time to stand up to bullies like Trump and the NRA. They've had their way too long, and with disastrous consequences. New research shows that, contrary to what your parents told you, it doesn't always work--the bully doesn't always back down. However, a stand is taken and a pathway is opened to the future. For her act of courage in standing up to the NRA by being the first Presidential candidate to represent the majority of Americans who want sensible gun control, Hillary Clinton gains my admiration and my vote.

I wish the New York times would define what a gun zealot is. If their definition is anyone that wants to own a gun privately is a gun zealot, then they should come out and lead an effort to overturn the second amendment.
